node.text:
Behind-the-scenes at MSF’s supply warehouse in Brussels, where we loaded up approximately 100 tons of medical and relief supplies to send to Haiti. The cargo included emergency medical tents, water and sanitation supplies, and medical materials for the care of up to 30,000 patients.
⠀
We are continuing to respond to the earthquake that shook southern Haiti, and to provide medical care to the people who need it. MSF’s emergency response has expanded in the southern peninsula, specifically the provinces of Grand’Anse, Nippes, and Sud, which were the areas worst affected. Staff working in Port-au-Prince have also treated dozens of injured patients brought to the capital from the earthquake zone.
⠀
--
#haiti #haitiearthquake #emergencyresponse #medicalsupplies #cargoplane #portauprince #doctorswithoutborders

node.title: Haiti Earthquake: Sending 100 Tons of Emergency Supplies

node.text:
The highly contagious Delta variant of COVID-19 is spreading quickly across the globe and in the US. People are getting sick and dying. Health systems are being pushed to the brink of collapse.
⠀
The best way for everyone to protect themselves and others is to get vaccinated against COVID-19. But lifesaving vaccines are out of reach for most of the world—currently 98% of people in low-income countries still struggle to access these vaccines.
⠀
The longer the coronavirus spreads, the more new variants of concern, like Delta, will emerge—prolonging the pandemic for all of us.
⠀
--
#deltavariant #covid19 #pandemic #covidvaccine #vaccines #vaccineequity #health #doctorswithoutborders

node.title: 3 Things to Know About the Delta Variant

node.text:
On August 4, 2020, a massive explosion occurred in Lebanon’s capital, Beirut. Close to 200 people were killed, more than 6,000 were injured, and tens of thousands lost their homes. A year later, many of our staff still see and feel psychological wounds from the explosion: “It feels as if the explosion happened a few minutes ago.”
⠀
The disaster came at a difficult time as Lebanon was already dealing with an economic crisis marked by widespread poverty and rising inflation, as well as the COVID-19 pandemic. Public health facilities were struggling to meet the needs of COVID patients while also responding to those wounded by the explosion. MSF staff in Lebanon jumped into action, treating injured patients and people with chronic diseases who had difficulty accessing medical care. Our teams donated medical supplies to the Lebanese Red Cross and went door-to-door to assess people’s needs.
#beirut #beirutblast #doctorswithoutborders

node.title: A Year Later, Beirut Explosion Is Still Painful

node.text:
In the space of just 11 days in May, many Gazans saw their homes and livelihoods destroyed, and suffered long-lasting physical and psychological injuries. Many people were unable to access medical care as stocks of medications and medical supplies ran low. These experiences come on top of lingering physical and mental trauma from previous rounds of violence, as well as the ongoing Israeli blockade of the Gaza Strip.
⠀
We've been providing surgical and post-surgical assistance to victims of burns and trauma in Gaza for almost 15 years. One MSF clinic in Gaza city was damaged by airstrikes and put out of service for a few days, but outpatient consultations at the clinic resumed on May 20th. Since the bombing stopped, we've scaled up all of our regular medical activities.
⠀
Urgent humanitarian aid is still needed.

node.title: Gaza: Trauma Continues Long After the Bombing Stops

node.text:
"I'm really happy right now! I had been waiting for it." For many bedridden people, their caregivers, and communities in remote areas, trying to reach Covid vaccination sites is a difficult and complicated process. They cannot be left out, and vaccines needs to be brought to them.
⠀
With support from MSF, @puertoricosalud is focused on bringing COVID-19 vaccines to communities that are hard to reach, that no one is currently serving. Community leaders are the link that refer vulnerable groups lacking access. The Dept of Health is providing the doses, and the Colegio de Profesionales de Enfermería de Puerto Rico is aiding in the safe storage of the vaccines.
⠀
---
#vaccinated #puertorico #doctorswithoutborders #covid #covid19 #vacunados #vacuna #community #vaccineequity

node.title: Vaccinating Against COVID-19 in Puerto Rico

node.text:
This was a really good moment. Meet Bonifácia de Oliveira, who celebrated her 109th birthday in a COVID-19 ward in Tefé Regional Hospital and a few days later, recovered and went home with her family: "She overcame something impossible."
⠀
Her strong spirit and sense of humor made a deep impact on the @msf_brasil team. In January, Tefé was among the remote towns in the Amazon region affected by the collapse of the health system in the state capital, Manaus. Between November and March, the MSF team in Tefé helped staff at the regional hospital establish protocols that improved the quality of patient care, giving people like Bonifácia a better chance of survival.
❤️❤️ #covid19 #patient #amazonia #amazonas #brazil #medicossemfronteiras #doctorswithoutborders

node.title: 109-Year-Old Grandmother Recovers from COVID-19 in Brazil's Amazon Region

node.text:
Seeing friends for the first time, cookouts, HUGS...we asked the amazing staff at @bmshealthcenter and community members in Brooklyn, New York what they look forward to after being fully vaccinated against Covid-19. BMS continues to provide free vaccinations in several locations in Brownsville and East New York.

What will you do?

Doctors Without Borders worked with BMS from February-April 2021 to expand access to COVID-19 vaccinations to two neighborhoods that were particularly hard hit by the COVID-19 pandemic. Getting vaccinated is the best thing we can do to protect ourselves, our communities, and our hospitals. In many countries, covid vaccines still aren't available and accessible, and we're fighting for vaccine equity so this pandemic ends for everyone, everywhere. #doctorswithoutborders #brooklyn #covid #vaccinated #nyc #bmshealthcenter #brownsville #frontlineworkers #healthworkers

node.title: Life After Getting Your Covid Shot: What are you looking forward to?

node.text:
"I shared some of those same concerns...the history that our people have had in this nation relative to vaccinations...I'm glad I did this today." Shoutout to @bmshealthcenter, Reverend Brawley, and St. Paul Community Baptist Church who are hard at work getting the community vaccinated in Brownsville and East New York. If you're in Brooklyn, give BMS a follow, a share, and learn more.

We partnered with @bmshealthcenter with logistical and admin support to help expand access to COVID-19 vaccinations from February to April 2021. BMS continues to provide covid vaccination shots.

--
#brooklyn #covid19 #getvaccinated #vaccineequity #equity #getyourshot #health #doctorswithoutborders #vaccine #community #communityhealth #brownsville #nyc

node.text:
Fighting in Ethiopia’s Tigray region has displaced hundreds of thousands of people. 

Most are staying with host families in the region, while tens of thousands of others have taken shelter at informal sites or are still hiding in the bush or the mountains. Most have been deprived of medical care for months and have received little humanitarian assistance.

We first arrived in the town of Shire in December. Food, safe water, and psychosocial support are just a few of the needs. 
---
#doctorswithoutborders #tigray #health #medicalcare #ethiopia

node.title: Tigray Crisis: Providing Medical Care for Hundreds of Thousands

node.text:
"The war affected me psychologically. But it also gave me the motivation to keep drawing." - Meet Amani Al Ali, a cartoonist who stayed on in Idlib city, even after it emptied out, in order to take care of her mother.

Imad Youssef, a former construction worker, is unemployed and worries about the future in Idlib for his family and for other displaced people—especially those living in the camps and informal settlements. “They have paid heavily with their lives and livelihoods,” he says. 
 
Abu Alaa, a citizen journalist, asks how people in western countries would feel if they were forced from their homes and homelands. Ten years later, he still carries the key to the house he left behind.

#syria #war #conflict #displacement #doctorswithoutborders #cartoonist #Syria10 #idlib #tenyears #forcedfromhome

node.title: Syria in 2021: Three stories on war, family, and an uncertain future

node.text:
These are the experiences and voices of Syrians we’ve met along the way in Idlib, in overcrowded camps and settlements still vulnerable to airstrikes. They are the survivors of a decade of war.

Khalaf Al Malla is a schoolteacher who fled Raqqa after his home was raided by the Islamic State. During his last two months there, he felt like a prisoner confined to his home: "Going out meant getting killed, either mentally or physically."

Fatima Al Ali and her family endured many hardships in Raqqa, but were not able to leave. She also lived in constant fear during the coalition offensive, with airstrikes raining down and IS taking over people's homes.

#syria #war #conflict #displacement #notatarget #doctorswithoutborders #nowayout #health #syrians #idlib #tenyears

node.title: No Way Out: 10 Years of War in Syria

node.title: Why planetary health matters to all of us

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) on September 10, 2021. May be an image of text.

node.text:
A medic on MSF’s Kunduz team describes his experience during the recent fighting in August and the work that is taking place now.⁣
⁣
In 2015, our Doctors Without Borders hospital in Kunduz, Afghanistan, was destroyed by US airstrikes. Forty-two people were killed, including patients, MSF staff, and caretakers.⁣
⁣
For the last few years, we have been working to rebuild a new trauma center in the city, even amid escalating conflict between the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan (also known as the Taliban) and Afghan government forces.⁣
⁣
During the intense clashes last month, MSF transformed its Kunduz office space into a temporary trauma unit to care for wounded people. On August 16, these patients were transferred to the nearly-finished Kunduz Trauma Center. This facility will employ 300 Afghans when it is fully operational, including staff members who survived the initial US attack six years ago. Many local people still need significant trauma care.⁣
⁣
“Today it is busy but calm. We’re recruiting new staff, and the final steps of the construction process are taking place all around us....” - Swipe through to read the rest on opening a new trauma center amid conflict and upheaval. ⁣
⁣
—⁣
#afghanistan #doctorswithoutborders #msf #trauma #kunduz #health #medic ⁣

We started doing lifesaving surgery on two patients while also doing everything possible to keep the other two alive We eventually poceee to operate on them too. In the end, one patient died, but three survived, which is quite remarkable- they all had very severe gunshot wounds and bomb blast injuries. While waiting for space to open up in the operating theater, and trying to keep the other two alive in the emergency room, we still needed to assist other patients who had come in and needed care.'.

node.text:
One year ago, Europe’s largest camp for displaced people—Moria camp on the Greek island of Lesbos—was destroyed by several fires that erupted across September 8th and 9th, 2020. 

Following the fires, the EU and Greek leaders promised “a fresh new start” on migration, but have instead continued to deny basic rights and dignity for asylum seekers and migrants searching for safety in Europe.

“The night of the fire we were so scared,” said Ali*, a survivor of torture in Syria who has lived on Lesbos for a year and a half. “For almost two weeks, we were homeless in the streets. It felt like you were under siege in Syria. There was no water, not even [a] toilet. It was shameful for Europe...There is no difference between the old Moria and [Kara Tepe] camp."

Miriam*, from Afghanistan, and her family were also living in the camp when the flames erupted. "Everywhere we looked, there was fire. We were in the middle of it, so we went to the mountains to protect ourselves. After the fires, we were in the streets for around ten days. We didn’t have any food and water." They now live in Kara Tepe. "My little girl tends to [show] aggressive behaviors because of what she has witnessed here. My wish is to get better psychologically. And to be able to go to work, me and my husband and live like a normal person."

MSF’s patients continue to report deteriorating health and mental health related to the arbitrary asylum process, a fear of deportation, and precarious living conditions.

"In Greece, the future looks more dystopian than ever...the EU and Greek [authorities] are [preparing] a new center on Samos Island [that will] trap refugees in prison-like conditions." - Konstantinos Psykakos, MSF’s head of mission in @msfgreece. We repeat our call for the European Commission, Greece, and EU States to implement policies that are focused on protecting and assisting refugees and asylum—not on ways to deter, stop, and deport those who are seeking safety in Europe. 

Photo credits: @evgenia__chr, Enri Canaj/Magnum, Evgenia Chorou 

--
#migration #asylum #standwithrefugees #fire #emergency  #greece #syria #afghanistan #mentalhealth #Greekfires #Moria

node.text:
Behind-the-scenes at MSF’s supply warehouse in Brussels, where we loaded up approximately 100 tons of medical and relief supplies to send to Haiti. The cargo included emergency medical tents, water and sanitation supplies, and medical materials for the care of up to 30,000 patients.
⠀
We are continuing to respond to the earthquake that shook southern Haiti, and to provide medical care to the people who need it. MSF’s emergency response has expanded in the southern peninsula, specifically the provinces of Grand’Anse, Nippes, and Sud, which were the areas worst affected. Staff working in Port-au-Prince have also treated dozens of injured patients brought to the capital from the earthquake zone.
⠀
--
#haiti #haitiearthquake #emergencyresponse #medicalsupplies #cargoplane #portauprince #doctorswithoutborders

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) on September 04, 2021. May be an image of 2 people and outdoors.

node.text:
Meet Kenny the camel – he helps transport measles vaccines and medical supplies through the mountains of hard-to-reach Jebel Marra, Darfur.
⠀
MSF is one of the few organizations that is able to operate fully here, and has been working closely with the local community to carry out our measles vaccination and treatment campaign. Our teams aim to vaccinate 95% of children between nine months and 15 years old and to provide them with vitamin A supplements as part of a malnutrition prevention and treatment plan.
⠀
© Anna Bylund/MSF
#darfur #sudan #measles #vaccines #vaccinations #medicalsupplies #community #doctorswithoutborders

node.text:
The highly contagious Delta variant of COVID-19 is spreading quickly across the globe and in the US. People are getting sick and dying. Health systems are being pushed to the brink of collapse.
⠀
The best way for everyone to protect themselves and others is to get vaccinated against COVID-19. But lifesaving vaccines are out of reach for most of the world—currently 98% of people in low-income countries still struggle to access these vaccines.
⠀
The longer the coronavirus spreads, the more new variants of concern, like Delta, will emerge—prolonging the pandemic for all of us.
⠀
--
#deltavariant #covid19 #pandemic #covidvaccine #vaccines #vaccineequity #health #doctorswithoutborders

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) on August 31, 2021. May be an image of 1 person.

node.text:
Julekha is a Rohingya refugee living in Cox’s Bazar: “My hope for the future is to have a happy life: to have food, clothes and freedom of movement.
⠀
In Myanmar, we suffered severe violence and we couldn’t stand up to it any longer. We had to run from one place to another to save our lives and we were starving. In the end we were forced to leave [for Bangladesh].
⠀
Here I live with many sufferings. I lost everything, including my shelter and my household essentials, in the fire.”
⠀
In March 2021, a fire spread rapidly, destroying the shelters of 50,000 people and six health clinics, including one run by MSF. The deteriorating living conditions, and an uncertain future, has created a mental health crisis among the Rohingya people in Cox’s Bazar. From January to December 2020, MSF teams providers 36,027 group and 32,336 individual mental health consultations in the camps - a 61% increase compared to the previous year.
⠀
Photo by @ysfsayman 
#rohingya #refugee #coxsbazar #refugeecamp #refugeestory #bangladesh #refugeecrisis #mentalhealth #doctorswithoutborders #portrait #standwithrefugees

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) on August 26, 2021. May be an image of outdoors and text that says '" We are refugees, yet human. We have dreams. We need medical assistance when we are sick. We need food when we are hungry. We need shelter. I beg of everyone from the outer world to treat us as human. " Refugee and MSF outreach volunteer Nur Boshor Cox's Bazar, Bangladesh'.

node.text:
Nur Boshor* was one among the hundreds of thousands of Rohingya people who fled to Bangladesh four years ago – and now works as a daily volunteer with our outreach team in Cox’s Bazar.
⠀
Rohingya refugees are not allowed to hold jobs, and can only earn a very small wage as volunteers with organizations working in the camp. Here, Nur explains why Rohingya volunteers are a vital part of the team and expresses his hopes to return home in the future.
⠀
Image description: “We are refugees, yet human. We have dreams. We need medical assistance when we are sick. We need food when we are hungry. We need shelter. I beg of everyone from the outer world to treat us as human.”
⠀
Photo: A section of the Jamtoli refugee camp in Cox’s Bazar – 2020 © Hasnat Sohan/MSF
*Name has been changed
#rohingya #refugee #refugeestory #bangladesh #refugeecamp #coxsbazar #refugeecrisis #doctorswithoutborders #standwithrefugees

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) on August 26, 2021. May be an image of outdoors and text that says '" We are refugees, yet human. We have dreams. We need medical assistance when we are sick. We need food when we are hungry. We need shelter. I beg of everyone from the outer world to treat us as human. " Refugee and MSF outreach volunteer Nur Boshor Cox's Bazar, Bangladesh'.

Photo by Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) on August 26, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'In 1962, the army took power in Myanmar and enacted martial law. From that time, gradually they started neglecting us and torturing [us] [us].l In 1974, for the first time, they denied our citizenship status. Torture and ethnic cleansing increased. My family tolerated it until 2017-when we finally decided to leave. We left our belongings, land, houses-everything. The Myanmar army at that time established checkpoints on the [route] and indiscriminately fired at us. We lost many souls back there while fleeing.'.

Photo by Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) on August 26, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'The situation in the camps is (getting] worse day by day. People have no jobs. People depend on rations from food programs and [are given only 1,017 Bangladeshi taka [about US$12] per month for a family. How can a family survive with this small amount? We can only afford rice and lentils-fish, meat, or much-needed medicines are far [too expensive].'.

Photo by Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) on August 26, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'I worked in the development sector back in Myanmar. A few days after ۱[ arrived in Bangladesh], joined MSF as a daily volunteer Rohingya people have their own language and culture. Only a Rohingya can understand what another Rohingya says and wants. When we were in Myanmar, many pregnant women died in the hospital just because they could not express their feelings and condition properly to non-native speaking doctors. Gradually, people became afraid of hospitals and clinics.'.

Photo by Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) on August 26, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Now [in Bangladesh] Rohingya volunteers with MSF] go door to door and discuss health issues, try to explain the importance of seeking medical assistance, and try to remove their long-held fear of doctors and hospitals. These things are only possible from a Rohingya volunteer.'.

Photo by Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) on August 26, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Many [people know] want to go back to Myanmar, as they face insecurity in the camps. am also keen to go back to my soil. [But] not now, as the situation is not under control there. We would be facing horror again if we go. We are refugees, yet human. We have dreams. We need medical assistance when we are sick. We We need food when we are hungry. We need shelter. beg of everyone from the outer world to treat us as human. We want epatriation as soon as possible.We want to go home.'.
Photo by Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) on August 25, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, standing and outdoors.

node.text:
Stateless and stranded 4 years later: In August 2017, hundreds of thousands of Rohingya people fled Myanmar following a targeted campaign of violence.
⠀
Today, nearly 900,000 Rohingya are now living in what has become the world’s largest refugee camp, in the Cox’s Bazar district of Bangladesh. The camps are a sea of shelters made from bamboo and plastic sheeting, and cut off from the world by barbed wire and razor fencing.
⠀
This refuge was supposed to be a temporary solution. As a result, Rohingya people are forced to make impossible choices about their futures. Some make the dangerous journey on trafficking boats to Malaysia even though there’s a chance the boats get caught by authorities and sent back. Some have agreed to be relocated to the island of Bhasan Char, a sandbar that has never been inhabited. Upon arrival, people are not allowed to leave. Others have decided to return to Myanmar, which plummeted further into crisis after a military coup early this year.
⠀
On top of this, Rohingya people are not given refugee status in Bangladesh, meaning they are denied the right to education, employment, free movement, and access to social security or public assistance.
⠀
Click our link in bio and this image again to learn more about the Rohingya refugee crisis.
2018 © Robin Hammond/NOOR
#rohingya #refugees #bangladesh #myanmar #refugeecamp #coxsbazar #refugeecrisis #doctorswithoutborders #standwithrefugees #health #mentalhealth

node.text:
A magnitude 7.2 earthquake hit Hait on August 14th. More than 2,200 people have died. Over 12,000 people have been injured, and thousands more have lost their homes. We’re providing medical care and getting emergency supplies to affected areas.

Video: aerial footage en route to Jérémie, where an MSF team is performing surgeries and supporting local health workers. #haiti #haitiearthquake #health #emergency #emergencymedicine

buttons.text: COVID-19 vaccines go through many tests for safety and effectiveness and are then monitored closely. (Source: World Health Organization)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) on August 23, 2021. May be an image of text.

node.text:
Haiti Update: 100 tons of emergency supplies have landed in Haiti over the weekend. The cargo includes items for setting up emergency medical structures and offices for operations using tents, materials to install emergency drinking water supply systems for at least 30,000 people, and medical supplies for the care of 30,000 patients, including items for stabilization, first aid, vaccination, and blood collection.
⠀
—
#haitiearthquake #haiti #earthquake #emergency #medicalsupplies #doctorswithoutborders

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) in Jeremie, Haiti. May be an image of 4 people and people standing.

node.text:
Meeting this staff in Haiti❤️

After the earthquake, we sent medical supplies and a medical team from Port-au-Prince, including two surgeons and an operating room nurse, to travel to Jérémie to begin working in St. Antoine’s hospital, and supporting hospital workers as earthquake survivors needed surgeries.

From MSF Dr. Xavier Kernizan, a Haitian surgeon, after arriving in Jérémie: 

"The staff at Saint Antoine Hospital did extraordinary work with the few staff and resources they had. Many patients were already cleaned and their wounds were debrided when we arrived. Some had external fixators to set broken bones, and some patients had already been referred to Port-au-Prince by air. A number of doctors who were originally from this region also returned from their jobs elsewhere to support the hospital.

So when we arrived, we asked, "What can we do for you?" We picked up where they started. And so we operated on many patients...we're shrinking the pool of patients waiting for treatment, waiting for surgery." - Xavier Kernizan, an orthopedic surgeon who normally works with MSF in the capital, Port-au-Prince, but joined an MSF team sent to the affected region to treat injuries, including bone fractures. 

Click the link in bio and this image again to read more from Dr. Kernizan on what's happening. Photo: Steven Aristil/MSF @steven_aristil 
#Haiti #haitiearthquake #earthquake #healthcareworkers #healthworkers #health #orthopedics #emergency #surgery

HAITI DOMINICAN REPUBLIC HAITI EARTHQUAKE EPICENTER MMI* Jérémie • Port-au-Prince IV Miragoâne Port-à-Piment Les Cayes Port-Salut CARIBBEANSEA'.

node.text:
Today our cargo plane is preparing to deliver more medical and emergency supplies to Haiti.
⠀
Our teams are providing urgent medical care to people affected by the Haiti earthquake. On August 14, a magnitude 7.2 earthquake struck the country's southern region. More than 1,900 people have died and some 9,900 people have been injured. Homes and vital infrastructure, including medical facilities, have been destroyed and damaged in the affected region. Some hospitals had to evacuate their patients, and some lack medical equipment and medicines. Aftershocks, and heavy rains from Tropical Storm Grace have caused additional suffering.
⠀
In Port-au-Prince, an MSF emergency medical team assisted patients in Sud province and sent emergency supplies, including first aid kits, tents for emergency clinics, medicines, and supplies for blood transfusions and plaster casts. In Les Cayes, a team is providing supplies and staff to work in the general hospital. In Port-Salut, a team is stabilizing the wounded and providing surgical and follow-up care. In the more remote location of Les Anglais, a team is assessing needs and transporting patients.
⠀
We plan to send more medical staff to help, including surgeons.
⠀
Photos by Stanley Louis/AFP and MSF
Click our link in bio and this image again to learn more about our emergency response in Haiti.
#haiti #earthquake #emergency #portauprince #medicalcare #medicalsupplies #cargoplane #doctorswithoutborders
